internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Consider the given data.

 

x 1 2 2.5 3 4 5
f(x) 0 5 7 6.5 2 0

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can one generate a divided difference table?

worksheet.stem:
Calculate f(3.4) using Newton’s interpolating polynomials of order 1 through 3. Choose the sequence of the points for your estimates to attain the best possible accuracy. That is, the points should be centered around and as close as possible to the unknown. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of f(3.4) = __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
x1 = 3                f(x1) = 6.5

x2 = 4                f(x2) = 2

x3 = 2.5             f(x3) = 7

x4 = 5                f(x4) = 0

Note that  based purely on the distance from the unknown, the fourth point would be (2, 5). However, because it provides better balance and is located only a little bit farther from the unknown, the point at (5, 0) is chosen.

The following difference table can be used to generate the divided differences:

 

x f(x) First Second Third
3 6.5 –4.5 –2.3333 1.43333
4 2 –3.3333 0.533333  
2.5 7 –2.8    
5 0      

 

First order

 

%media:formula3.mml%

 

%media:formula1.mml%

 

Second order

 

%media:formula42.mml%

 

%media:formula2.mml%

 

Third order

 

%media:formula42.mml%

 

%media:formula6.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the concept of Lagrange interpolation.

worksheet.stem:
Calculate f(3.4) using Lagrange polynomial of order 1 through 3. Choose the sequence of the points for your estimates to attain the best possible accuracy. That is, the points should be centered around and as close as possible to the unknown. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of f(3.4) = __a__.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Is a divided difference table used to find f(4)?

worksheet.stem:
Consider the given data.

 

x 1 2 3 5 6
f(x) 4.75 4 5.75 19.75 36

 

Calculate f(4) using Newton’s interpolating polynomials of order 1 through 4. Choose your base points to attain good accuracy. That is, the points should be centered around and as close as possible to the unknown. What do your results indicate regarding the order of the polynomial used to generate the data in the table? (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of f(4) = __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The points can be ordered so that they are close to and centered around the unknown. A divided difference table can then be developed as follows:

 

x f(x) First Second Third Fourth
3 5.75 7 1.75 0.333333 0.041667
5 19.75 5.25 2.75 0.25  
2 4 8 1.75    
6 36 6.25      
1 4.75        

 

The general formula for Newton's interpolating polynomial is as follows:

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

First order

 

%media:formula11.mml%

 

Second order

 

%media:formula12.mml%

 

Third order

 

%media:formula13.mml%

 

Fourth order

 

%media:formula14.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the concept of the Lagrange polynomial.

worksheet.stem:
Consider the given data.

 

x 1 2 3 5 6
f(x) 4.75 4 5.75 19.75 36

 

Calculate f(4) using Lagrange polynomials of order 1 through 3. Choose your base points to attain good accuracy. That is, the points should be centered around and as close as possible to the unknown. What do your results indicate regarding the order of the polynomial used to generate the data in the table? (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of f(4) = __a__.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Ohm’s law states that the voltage drop V across an ideal resistor is linearly proportional to the current i flowing through the resister as in V = i R, where R is the resistance. However, real resistors may not always obey Ohm’s law. Suppose that you performed some very precise experiments to measure the voltage drop and corresponding current for a resistor. The following results suggest a curvilinear relationship rather than the straight line represented by Ohm’s law:

 

i –2 –1 –0.5 0.5 1 2
V –637 –96.5 –20.5 20.5 96.5 637

 

To quantify this relationship, a curve must be fit to the data. Because of measurement error, regression would typically be the preferred method of curve fitting for analyzing such experimental data. However, the smoothness of the relationship, as well as the precision of the experimental methods, suggests that interpolation might be appropriate.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which arguments are required to fit the data using MATLAB in-built function?

worksheet.stem:
Use a fifth-order interpolating polynomial to fit the given data. (Round the final answers to the nearest integer.)

 

The interpolating polynomial V = __a__i5 + __b__i4 + __c__i3 + __d__i2 + __e__i + __f__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
A MATLAB session  provides a handy way to solve this problem.

 

>> format short
>> i = [-2 -1 -0.5 0.5 1 2];
>> V = [-637 -96.5 -20.5 20.5 96.5 637];
>> p = polyfit(i,V,5)

p =
    0.0000    0.0000   74.0000   -0.0000   22.5000   -0.0000

 

The interpolating polynomial is

 

%media:formula19.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which arguments are required to fit the data using MATLAB in-built function?

worksheet.stem:
Compute V for i = 0.10. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of V for i = 0.10 is __A__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The polyval function can be used to determine the interpolation at i = 0.1.

 

>> i = [-2 -1 -0.5 0.5 1 2];
>> V = [-637 -96.5 -20.5 20.5 96.5 637];
>> polyval(p,0.10)

 

Output

 

ans =
    2.3240

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Does the minimum error occur for the second-order version?

worksheet.stem:
You measure the voltage drop V across a resistor for a number of different values of current i. The results are as follows:

 

i 0.5 1.5 2.5 3.0 4.0
V –0.45 –0.6 0.7 1.88 6.0

 

Use first- through fourth-order polynomial interpolation to estimate the voltage drop for i = 2.3. Interpret your results. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The voltage drop for i = 2.3 is __A__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Since we do not know the proper order of the interpolating polynomial, this problem is suited for Newton interpolation. First, order the points so that they are as close to and as centered about the unknown as possible.

x0 = 2.5               f(x0) = 0.7

x1 = 1.5                f(x1) = –0.6

x2 = 3                   f(x2) = 1.88

x3 = 0.5                f(x3) = –0.45

x4 = 4                   f(x4) = 6

The results of applying Newton’s polynomial at i = 2.3 are as follows:

 

Order f(x) Error
0 0.7 –0.26
1 0.44 –0.11307
2 0.32693 –0.00082
3 0.32611 0.011174
4 0.33729  

 

The minimum error occurs for the second-order version, so we conclude that the interpolation is 0.32693.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Does the minimum error occur for the second-order version?

worksheet.stem:
The current in a wire is measured with great precision as a function of time:

 

t 0 0.25 0.5 0.75 1.00
i 0 6.24 7.75 4.85 0.000

 

Determine i at t = 0.23. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The value of i at t = 0.23 is __A__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Since we do not know the proper order of the interpolating polynomial, this problem is suited for Newton interpolation. First, order the points so that they are as close to and as centered about the unknown as possible.

 

x0 = 0.25               f(x0) = 6.24

x1 = 0                     f(x1) = 0

x2 = 0.5                  f(x2) = 7.75

x3 = 0.75                f(x3) = 4.85

x4 = 1                      f(x4) = 0

The results of applying Newton’s polynomial at t = 0.23 are as follows:

 

Order f(x) Error
0 6.24 –0.4992
1 5.7408 0.174064
2 5.91486 0.004239
3 5.91910 –0.01474
4 5.90436 0

 

The minimum error occurs for the second-order version, so we conclude that the interpolation is 5.91486.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering
ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file function, that uses polyfit and polyval for polynomial interpolation.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The result is as follows:

True value = 5.4848.

The percentage error = 0.0602%.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax of the MATLAB function polyint?

worksheet.stem:
Test the obtained function from the previous question of the same section using the following script.

 

clear,clc,clf,format compact
x = [1 2 4 8];
fx = @(x) 10*exp(−0.2*x);
y = fx(x);
yint = polyint(x,y,3)
ytrue = fx(3)
et = abs((ytrue − yint) / ytrue)*100.

(Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The result is as follows:

True value = __a__.

The Percentage error = __b__%.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Function

 

function yint = polyint(x,y,xx)
% polyint: Polynomial interpolation
% yint = polyint(x,y,xx): Uses an (n - 1)-order
%   polynomial based on n data points (x, y)
%   to determine a value of the dependent variable (yint)
%   at a given value of the independent variable, xx.
% input:
%   x = independent variable
%   y = dependent variable
%   xx = value of independent variable at which
%        interpolation is calculated
% output:
%   yint = interpolated value of dependent variable
n = length(x);
if length(y)~=n, error('x and y must be same length'); end
p = polyfit(x,y,n-1);
yint = polyval(p,xx);

 

Output

 

int =
    5.4848
ytrue =
    5.4881
et =
    0.0602

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

worksheet.stem:
The following data comes from a table that was measured with high precision. Use the Newton interpolating polynomial to determine y at x = 3.5. Properly order all the points and then develop a divided difference table to compute the derivatives. Note that a polynomial will yield an exact value. Your solution should prove that your result is exact. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

x 0 1 2.5 3 4.5 5 6
y 26 15.5 5.375 3.5 2.375 3.5 8

 

The value of y at x = 3.5 is __A__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Order all the points and then develop a divided difference table to compute the derivatives.

 

x y first second third
3 3.5 –0.75 1.5 0
4.5 2.375 –1.5 1.5 0
2.5 5.375 –0.75 1.5 0
5 3.5 –3 1.5 0
1 15.5 –1.5 1.5  
6 8 –3    
0 26      

 

%media:formula20.mml%

 

%media:formula21.mml%

 

%media:formula22.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The following data are measured precisely:

 

t 2 2.1 2.2 2.7 3 3.4
Z 6 7.752 10.256 36.576 66 125.168

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the concept of divided difference.

worksheet.stem:
Use Newton interpolating polynomials to determine z at t = 2.5. Make sure that you order your points to attain the most accurate results. What do your results tell you regarding the order of the polynomial used to generate the data? (Round the final answer to the nearest whole number.)

 

The value of z at t = 2.5 is __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The points can be ordered and a divided difference table can be generated as follows:

 

x z First Second Third
2.7 36.576 52.64 46 12
2.2 10.256 25.04 49.6 12
2.1 7.752 64.72 47.2  
3 66 60    
2 6      

 

Zero order

 

%media:formula23.mml%

 

First order

 

%media:formula24.mml%

 

Second order

 

%media:formula25.mml%

 

Third order

 

%media:formula26.mml%

 

Because the fourth derivative is effectively zero, this result implies that the data was generated with a cubic equation and the final result is perfect.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

worksheet.stem:
Use a third-order Lagrange interpolating polynomial to determine z at t = 2.5. (Round the final answer to the nearest whole number.)

 

The value of z at t = 2.5 is __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
For Lagrange, the order of the points does not matter but it’s always good to pick the points that are the closest to the unknown.

x1 = 2.1               f(x1) = 7.752

x2 = 2.2               f(x2) = 10.256

x3 = 2.7                f(x3) = 36.576

x4 = 3                    f(x4) = 66

Third order

 

%media:formula27.mml%

 

%media:formula46.mml%%media:formula46.mml% %media:formula48.mml%                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

%media:formula29.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The following data for the density of water versus temperature come from a table that was measured with high precision.

 

T, °C 0 4 8 12 16
Density, g/cm3 0.99987 1 0.99988 0.99952 0.99897

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Use the MATLAB polyfit function to determine the polynomial.

worksheet.stem:
Use inverse interpolating polynomial to fit the given data. Base your estimate on a third-order interpolating polynomial. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The best-fit polynomial D = __a__ × 10–7T3 + __b__ × 10–5T2 + __c__ × 10–5T + __d__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
We use MATLAB to fit the last 4 points with a cubic:

 

clear,clc,clf
format short g
T=[4 8 12 16];
D=[1 0.99988 0.99952 0.99897];
a=polyfit(T,D,3)

a =
  1.3021e-007 -1.0625e-005  8.2917e-005      0.99983

 

Therefore, the best-fit polynomial is

 

%media:formula30.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

worksheet.stem:
Determine the root with the Newton-Raphson method (by hand) with an initial guess of T = 14 °C until the 2nd iteration. Determine the temperature corresponding to a density of 0.999245 g/cm3. Be careful regarding roundoff errors. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The root is __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The roots problem to determine the answer can then be set up as follows:

 

%media:formula32.mml%

 

%media:formula33.mml%

 

The derivative required by Newton-Raphson is

 

%media:formula34.mml%

 

First iteration

 

%media:formula35.mml%

 

%media:formula36.mml%

 

Error estimate

 

%media:formula37.mml%

 

Second iteration

 

%media:formula38.mml%

 

%media:formula39.mml%

 

Error estimate

 

%media:formula40.mml%

 

The entire calculation can be summarized as follows:

 

i x f(x) f'(x) εa
0 14 2.063 × 10–5 –1.380 × 10–4  
1 14.1495 –1.148 × 10–7 –1.396 × 10–4 1.057%
2 14.14868     0.006%

 

Thus, the answer is 14.14868 oC.
